The attached set of exemplifications illustrate the possibleeffects on individual authorities of the alternative options discussedin the Home Secretary's Report on the 1982-83 settlement. The firstthree sets (A1 to A3J are based on the higher public expenditureprovision of l8150m for local authority current expenditure recommendedby the Secretary of State for the Environment and a 1.50 per weekaverage guideline for council rent increases. It has not yet beenpossible to exemplify the effects of a minimum 1.50 increase.Table A1 shows a 56% grant, A2 a 54% and A3 a 50% grant.2. The second three sets (B1 to B3) are based on the lower planningtotal of l7800m for current expenditure previously considered byCabinet, and a 3.54 rent guideline.3. The exemplifications for A2 are shown for all authorities. A1,A3,B1, B2 and B3 are shown for only the major spending authorities,and for a single page of non-metropolitan districts.4. If they were to budgetCONFIDENTIAL1 CONFIDENTIALin line with target there could be substantial rate reductions for . some authorities on a 56% r 5^% grant, particularly for thoseauthorities whose targets imply that they ought to make big expenditurereductions. But if they continue to spend more in line with theirpresent real level of expenditure (as in Cols 6-8) there could besubstantial holdback for many authorities, particularly those whichhave the steepest reductions in their targets, and substantial rateincreases. It is impossible to predict precisely in advance howauthorities will budget. But the two sets of possible budgetsexemplified in Cols 3-5 and Cols 6-8 indicate a broad range withinwhich most authorities may reasonably be expected to fall.6. Expenditure targets Individual cash expenditure targets for eachauthority in 1982-83 have been constructed as follows. First, fornon-housing expenditure they are constructed as to require thelargest reduction from the 1981-82 level of expenditure fromauthorities which were spending highest in relation to their grant-related expenditure assessment (GRE) in that year, or to t heir volumetargets for year or to both, and the lowest reductions from thosewhich had spent lowest on the same scales. The scaling used requireda 2% additional cut for each 10% by which an authority's revisedbudget total expenditure in 1981-82 exceeds its GRE and/or for each10% by which the volume of its current expenditure in its revisedbudget exceeds its volume target. The resulting changes are thensubjected to an upper and lower limit. At the upper end no authorityis set a target implying more than a 7% real terms reduction from anyauthority on grounds of realism. At the lower end authorities spendingat GRE and meeting their volume target in 1981-82 are not asked formore than a 1% reduction and no authority is allowed any real termsincrease.3. GREs A number of changes in GRE methodology for 1982-83 have beenprovisionally agreed by service Ministers and announced to the localauthority associations. The main changes concern education and personalsocial services and have the effect of significantly improving therelative position of London (particularly inner London) and other urbanareas.5* Block Grant Mechanisms MISC 21 have considered a number of optionsfor the block grant mechanisms which together with the GREs are thechief determinants of the grant distribution. The current exemplifica-tions are based on a steeper "poundage schedule" than last year with a25% 'taper* for spending above the threshold set 10% above GRE for eachclass. This means that each increment of expenditure will cost localauthorities more than last year in terms of increased rate poundage,and conversely that each reduction in expenditure will save them more.CONFIDENTIAL CONFIDENTIAL6.
